image.altText: England player Rachel Daly holds her neck while surrounded by Nigeria players at the FIFA Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: The Matildas meet Denmark for a spot in the quarter-finals of the FIFA Women's World Cup, after England takes on Nigeria in Brisbane. Follow live.

title.children: England has penalty overturned by VAR in knockout game against Nigeria ahead of Matildas' clash with Denmark

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's been a tight and tense tussle in the first half - with Nigeria having by far the better of the chances as they frequently went around England's back three to get balls into the box. A couple of great saves from Mary Earps and some telling blocks have kept England in it. Nigeria have not allowed England to settle one bit when they've had possession - charging them down and using their immense physicality to win the ball back. However, England will have questions of Honduran referee Melissa Borjas after she overruled her original decision to award a penalty. If nothing else, it's hard not to feel sorry for Ireland if that is not a penalty - because Hayley Raso's decisive incident in the opening game was far softer than that.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Half time: England 0-0 Nigeria

children.content: (Getty Images)
It's been a tight and tense tussle in the first half - with Nigeria having by far the better of the chances as they frequently went around England's back three to get balls into the box.
A couple of great saves from Mary Earps and some telling blocks have kept England in it.
Nigeria have not allowed England to settle one bit when they've had possession - charging them down and using their immense physicality to win the ball back.
(Getty Images)
However, England will have questions of Honduran referee Melissa Borjas after she overruled her original decision to award a penalty.
If nothing else, it's hard not to feel sorry for Ireland if that is not a penalty - because Hayley Raso's decisive incident in the opening game was far softer than that.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Well I can't believe that. It would have been a soft penalty, but it was still a penalty. There was clear contact from behind in the penalty area. England can't believe it - the Nigerians feel vindicated and the crowd are a bit of a mix between the two.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 35' NO PENALTY! VAR OVERTURNS IT!

children.content: (Getty Images)
Well I can't believe that.
It would have been a soft penalty, but it was still a penalty. There was clear contact from behind in the penalty area.
(Getty Images)
England can't believe it - the Nigerians feel vindicated and the crowd are a bit of a mix between the two.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's not amazing defending to be honest. Rasheedat Ajibade it was, barging into Rachel Daly. VAR is going to have a look at this, but it was very similar to Hayley Raso's penalty against Ireland earlier in the tournament - but with much more contact. VAR confirms penalty - or does it? Our referee is going over to the monitor. If Hayley Raso's one was a penalty, this is too.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 31' PENALTY ENGLAND!

children.content: It's not amazing defending to be honest.
Rasheedat Ajibade it was, barging into
Rachel Daly.
(Getty Images)
VAR is going to have a look at this, but it was very similar to Hayley Raso's penalty against Ireland earlier in the tournament - but with much more contact.
(Getty Images)
VAR confirms penalty - or does it? Our referee is going over to the monitor.
If Hayley Raso's one was a penalty, this is too.

image.altText: A man in a camouflage jacket with his arms crossed is spoken to in a police interview room

items.synopsis: Family and friends of the slain teen clapped and sighed with relief in court in Dubbo this morning when Craig Rumsby, 56, was jailed for at least 24 years.

title.children: For 24 years this man got away with murder. Today Michelle Bright's family finally saw justice

image.altText: A composite image of a man with glasses in a suit and tie, and a woman with long hair.

items.synopsis: The head of an inquiry into judicial fairness as part of the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann is now the one under the spotlight.

title.children: 'Significant lapse of judgement': ACT government slams early release of report into Bruce Lehrmann's prosecution

image.altText: Three brown brumbies with a small, brown foal stand in an open plain in Kosciuszko National Park.

items.synopsis: Environment Minister Penny Sharpe says reducing the population of feral horses in Kosciuszko National Park won't be achieved without aerial shooting.

title.children: Feral horses 'unsustainable': NSW government reconsiders aerial shooting in Kosciuszko

image.altText: A collage of two silhouettes, the KPMG logo, and cutouts of $100 notes.

items.synopsis: Consulting giant KPMG has been accused by whistleblowers of wasting public money, submitting inflated invoices and billing the Department of Defence for hours never worked.

title.children: It's raking in billions of dollars in public money. Now whistleblowers are accusing this consulting firm of ripping off the government

image.altText: A police exclusion zone following a fatal house fire on Russell Island

items.synopsis: Investigators are still sifting through the burnt-out house on Russell Island after the fire that killed a father and his five sons yesterday.

title.children: Police say cause of house fire requires 'closer scrutiny' after father and five sons killed

image.altText: Mushrooms stand on a patch of grass.

items.synopsis: Homicide detectives are still trying to get to the bottom of a suspected mushroom poisoning at a family meal in Victoria's east which led to the deaths of three people, who are being mourned as "pillars" of their community.

title.children: Daughter-in-law served poisonous mushroom meal that killed three, Victoria Police believe

image.altText: An aerial photo of a green cotton picker harvesting cotton.

items.synopsis: With almost $36 million in state government funding, the project at Moree aims to lower fertiliser and fuel emissions by displacing 1.4 million litres of imported diesel.

title.children: $36m for NSW farm to host green hydrogen, ammonia plant in bid for climate-positive cotton

image.altText: Two sets of gloved hands hold the head of a baby, its face scrunched up, while it is being born.

items.synopsis: Midwives across the country say workforce shortages are taking a heavy toll on maternity staff and the families they care for.

title.children: 'I feel complicit in care that harms women': Midwives reveal crisis inside Australia's maternity wards

image.altText: A woman in a large hat and sunglasses smiles broadly.

items.synopsis: Lawyers for billionaire Gina Rinehart seek to demolish a claim by a former business partner of her father Lang Hancock to a share of the jewel in her lucrative iron ore empire.

title.children: 'Fatal flaws' in argument underpin claim for slice of Gina Rinehart's iron ore empire, WA Supreme Court hears

image.altText: Composite image of a Federal Court Sign and a statue overlooking Roebourne.

items.synopsis: The Yindjibarndi Aboriginal Corporation seeks $500 million a year in compensation from Fortescue Metals Group, for losses caused by the company's Solomon Hub in WA.

title.children: 'Devastation': Court hears of 'economic and cultural loss' caused by Fortescue mines as native title dispute resumes

image.altText: Two people wearing remebrance T-shirts.

items.synopsis: Luke Gilbert is alleged to have approached two police officers with a knife before they shot him dead last October. A coronial inquest is underway that will consider whether police complied with policies and procedures.

title.children: Body-worn camera vision shown as inquest begins into fatal Airlie Beach police shooting

image.altText: A woman in a purple t-shirt reading vote yes weaving a basket while surrounded by others

items.synopsis: Supporters of the Yes campaign are still hopeful the referendum will pass but a growing number of No voters is putting it at risk, writes Dana Morse.

title.children: The Voice referendum campaign is becoming a tale of two polls and a political battle

image.altText: A blonde white man wears a pink shirt, while riding in the back of a pink car driven by a white blonde woman in a pink outfit.

items.synopsis: Just three weeks after its release, Greta Gerwig's Barbie has collected more than $1 billion at the global box office — and it's on track to become the biggest movie of the year.

title.children: Barbie has reached the 'Barbillion' milestone. Experts say its marketing was a 'masterclass'

image.altText: Three people in space suits, two omen with an elderly man in the centre.

items.synopsis: The pair will be the first mother and daughter and first from the Caribbean in space next week on a commercial voyage.

title.children: Mother and daughter will make history when they head to space this week

image.altText: Typhoon Khanun

items.synopsis: All remaining national contingents attending the World Scout Jamboree in South Korea will be evacuated due to a typhoon forecast to hit the country amid a sweltering heatwave.

title.children: Scouts to be evacuated from World Scout Jamboree ahead of Typhoon Khanun

image.altText: Rebel Wilson smiles towards the camera

items.synopsis: The 43-year-old has been in Savannah, Georgia filming her upcoming film Bride Hard, an action comedy where Wilson stars as a secret agent.

title.children: Rebel Wilson was hospitalised after a 'stunt accident'. She's working on one of the few films not affected by the actors strike

image.altText: A burger on a plate, with lettuce and tomato.

items.synopsis: Is eating a beef burger worse for your health than eating a lean grass-fed steak? And how much red meat should we really be eating? Katherine Livingstone weighs the evidence.

title.children: Is eating a beef burger worse for your health than eating a lean grass-fed steak?

image.altText: A barber shop with a sign telling people it's a male only sanctuary

items.synopsis: An Adelaide barbershop that bans women from entering its premises in order to provide its clients with a "male sanctuary" has applied for an exemption to the Equal Opportunity Act.

title.children: Barbershop applies for exemption from Equal Opportunity Act so it can continue ban on women

image.altText: A man with fair hair and skin, wearing a suit jacket and an open-necked shirt.

items.synopsis: A rape case highlighting sexual assault and harassment issues in the mining industry ends with a former fly-in fly-out worker being sentenced to five years in jail.

title.children: Woman whose life was 'flipped upside down' by mine-site rape proud of speaking out, as attacker jailed

image.altText: A cooked lamb roast in a clear dish with potatoes on a kitchen bench.

items.synopsis: The red meat industry concedes it could fall short of its ambitious target, but insists it still has seven years and a solid plan to get there.

title.children: Will your Sunday roast really be carbon neutral by 2030?

image.altText: Aerial shot of a large dam

items.synopsis: Alcoa could have its current plans to mine assessed by WA's environmental watchdog for the first time in history, following drinking water concerns.

title.children: Perth drinking water concerns could trigger Alcoa environmental review

image.altText: A woman sitting down on an adaptive bike wearing a helmet while smiling and looking at a man with a helmet and glasses.

items.synopsis: Coleen Kehoe became a paraplegic after a mountain bike riding accident. Adaptive bikes and trails have helped her, and husband Rick, get back on the track together.

title.children: 'He's proud of me': Former professional mountain biker overcomes adversity to ride with her husband again

image.altText: A little girl and boy in school uniform wait at the bus stop.

items.synopsis: Sutherland commuters have complained about unreliable services since new operator U-Go Mobility took over the bus contract, forcing the government to step in.

title.children: Alfie and Matilda are nervous getting the bus to school after it dropped them in the wrong spot four times in three weeks

image.altText: Donald Trump, wearing a navy suit, holds his red tie down to stop it flapping as he descends airplane stairs

items.synopsis: The former US president says "there is no way I can get a fair trial" and he will seek Judge Tanya Chutkan's recusal as well as a change of venue.

title.children: Donald Trump seeks new judge in election fraud case

image.altText: Three men, two old and one young, are wearing blue sports shirts with medals around their necks. They are happy.

items.synopsis: The famous sporting showdown on the Tiwi Islands drew local football fanatics and mainland tourists to Wurrumiyanga Oval on Sunday.

title.children: The triumph and defeat from the Tiwi Islands football grand final, in pictures

image.altText: Balupalu Yunupingu explains the importance of the message stick before handing it over to Noel Pearson.

items.synopsis: The confidence of Yes campaigners at Garma can be difficult to fathom when looking at the hard numbers and trend lines that usually dictate political campaigns, writes David Speers.

title.children: The numbers can't be ignored. Yes is behind, and it's trying new angles to appeal to anyone still on the fence

image.altText: Composite image of Andrew Forrest and Michael Woodley.

items.synopsis: With Fortescue and Pilbara native title holders unable to agree on compensation for "economic and cultural loss" caused by mining, the Federal Court will begin hearing evidence in Roebourne today.

title.children: Andrew Forrest's FMG, Pilbara traditional owners return to court over $500 million compensation battle

image.altText: David Fahey stands at the site of the former kurrajong tree, with one boot raised on the stump.

items.synopsis: A landmark tree that has guarded Morundah's pub for more than a century has been cut down by Essential Energy — and residents are not happy.

title.children: Power company apologises after community 'blindsided' by removal of 130-year-old tree

image.altText: An Aboriginal flag in the foreground, Parliament House in the background

items.synopsis: Millennials and members of Generation Z have never voted in a national referendum before, but they may decide whether the constitution changes this year.

title.children: Could young people lead Australia to vote Yes in the Voice to Parliament referendum?

image.altText: An illustration of a boy staring out a window from behind.

items.synopsis: Almost 33 per cent of Australians feel disconnected socially, and one in six feels severely lonely, according to a landmark study. But there are ways to feel less alone.

title.children: 'They feel really ashamed': Millions of Australians are lonely, but many find it hard to admit
